data.title: International Language Quarterly Volume 3, Issue 3 - National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled (NLS)
data.meta_description: All books listed in this publication are free to eligible individuals. Anyone living in the United States, as well as US citizens living abroad
data.meta_site_name: National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled (NLS) | Library of Congress
data.text:
Introduction

Welcome back to International Language Quarterly (ILQ)! ILQ’s mission is to help you keep up with the international language books that the National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled (NLS) is adding to its collection. ILQ is posted to the NLS website every three months. All books listed in this publication are free to eligible individuals. Anyone living in the United States, as well as US citizens living abroad, may qualify for service if they have a temporary or permanent visual or physical, perceptual, or reading disability that prevents them from using regular print materials.

Many of our International Language books come to us from other countries via the Marrakesh Treaty (DBGs and BRGs), but you will also find books produced by NLS (DBs), produced by network libraries (DBCs), and converted from cassette tapes or CDs (DBFs). All books listed in International Language Quarterly are available for immediate download from NLS BARD, the Braille and Audio Reading Download. To use BARD, contact your local braille and talking-book library or visit http://nlsbard.loc.gov for more information. The free BARD Mobile app, available for both iOS and Android operating systems, may be used to play books directly from your personal mobile device. Talking books may also be requested from your local braille and talking-book library on cartridge if your library makes use of Duplication on Demand. Hard copies of braille books may be requested through the Braille-on-Demand pilot program External. To obtain contact information for your local braille and talking-book library, visit Find Your Library or call 1-888-NLS-READ (1-888-657-7323).

This past quarter, NLS added books in 26 unique languages: Afrikaans, Albanian, Arabic, Chinese (Mandarin), Croatian, Czech, French, German, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Lithuanian, Panjabi, Persian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Somali, Spanish, Tagalog, Tigrinya, Ukrainian, Yiddish, and Yoruba.

NLS again added far more Spanish titles than just those featured in this ILQ issue—be sure to search in the Catalog or on BARD to see everything, especially the many books by Shakespeare in Spanish, only one of which appears here. Patrons have been enjoying non-fiction books in the “Historia Mínima” series, which includes brief histories of many Latin American countries, as well as broader topics like soccer and yoga. NLS also added new cookbooks in Spanish this past quarter.

This issue also features quite a few Spanish books by authors from the Dominican Republic, such as Rita Indiana and Frank Báez. You will also see many of the children’s and young adult books that were added as part of the inaugural NLS summer reading program, by authors like Kwame Alexander and Celia C. Pérez.

You’ll see two new braille books in Spanish, which includes the first Spanish braille book obtained via the Marrakesh Treaty: Aura by Carlos Fuentes, originally produced by an organization in Mexico.

Also under the Marrakesh Treaty, we were also able to expand our number of available languages thanks to MTM in Sweden, adding our first books in Tigrinya (spoken in Eritrea) as well as additional titles in Persian, Somali, and Yiddish. Thanks for keeping in mind that these MTM books need to be deleted or returned within six months. Two other new-to-the-collection languages were added through conversion of commercial audiobooks: the Bible in Tagalog (spoken in the Philippines) and Yoruba (spoken in West Africa).

Below you will find a selection of these featured titles and other popular international language books uploaded to BARD over the past three months. When available, full annotations may be found by searching for the books on BARD or NLS Catalog. While we strive to include titles and annotations in both the book’s original language and English, unfortunately we do not always have access to that information. Books acquired from other countries via Marrakesh and other means sometimes reach us with no English-language cataloguing records, and we lack in-house translation expertise in some languages. Capitalization, titles, and author names listed below are based on the NLS Catalog records. For more information, visit the International Language Collection website.

Whenever possible, book titles are provided first in English translation and second in the language of the book itself. When the book’s language uses a non-Roman character set, a transliteration is provided in parentheses next to the English title when available. Links are provided to download books directly from BARD.

Instructions for searching BARD

There are three options to find books in particular languages on the BARD website:

Choose your preferred languages by clicking the “language preference settings” link in the description under Search the Collection on the BARD home page or by going to “Account Settings” under “My BARD.” Click “Select this link to change your language preferences.” Check the boxes next to the language(s) in which you would like to read books. Click the “Update” button. Click “Back to BARD main page” to start searching for books in your preferred languages. NLS recommends this as the most efficient method. You may ask your local braille and talking-book library to update the preferred language setting in your account for you if necessary.

If you haven’t set your preferred languages or would like to find books in a language other than your preferred languages, you may also filter for books in a particular language while browsing, such as while looking at the “Recently added books and magazines” screen. You will find a “Filter by language” dropdown menu/combo box at the top of the screen. If you choose the language you have in mind from that list and click “Go,” you will see a list of applicable books in that language. This option will not appear if the page you are browsing only includes books in one language.

To search by keyword for books in a particular language on BARD, you may enter your search term in the main “Search the collection” edit box, then choose the language from the preferred language dropdown menu/combo box, and click “Go” to run the search.

If you plan to read the books via BARD Mobile, you may add them to your wishlist on the website and then download them on the app. You may find international language books using the iOS version of BARD Mobile by specifying English, Spanish, or Other on the search screen, but this feature is not yet available in the Android or Kindle Fire version.

Searching by language in the NLS Catalog

Results may be limited to a particular language on the Keyword and Advanced search screens in the NLS Catalog by entering your search term, clicking the Add Limits button, choosing your desired language from the list under the Language heading, and clicking search.

For example, if you were looking for Spanish books by Danielle Steel, you could go to nlscatalog.loc.gov, click Keyword search, enter Steel, Danielle in the search box, choose Author/Narrator as the type of search, then click add limits, choose Spanish from the language list, and click search.

For example, if you were looking for the Bridgertons series in French, you could go to nlscatalog.loc.gov, click Advanced search, enter Bridgertons in the search box, choose Series (KSER) as the type of search, then click add limits, choose French from the language list, and click search.
